results.title: The Pinnacle of fame
results.creator_credit: Richard Walker and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Dramatised documentary written and presented by Bill Peach recounting the efforts of three white Europeans to explore the Gippsland and Australian Alps regions. In 1840, Polish geologist and explorer, Paul Strzelecki joined forces with James Macarthur who was interested in exploring the region for grazing land. Strzelecki is considered the first white man to climb Australia’s highest mountain and reach the Kosciusko plateau. Another Polish explorer, Dr John Lhotsky, travelled through the region six years earlier collecting botanical specimens for European museum, but his efforts were not supported by the New South Wales government and his discoveries remain uncredited. Scottish settler, Angus McMillan, was exploring the area during the same period as Strzelecki but chose to conceal his discoveries until he could claim the land as his own. After persevering through hunger and hardship, Strzelecki stumbled across the ranges that bear his name before reaching Melbourne. Here he published details about his findings and the first detailed map of the region. McMillan was outraged when he read the news which omitted any reference to his exploration, furthermore, the rivers and lakes that he had discovered had been renamed by Strzelecki. Strzelecki argued that credit should be given to the explorer who shared his findings and benefits with the public. McMillan was eventually given credit for his exploration of the region while Lhotsky’s efforts failed.

results.title: East to west
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Dramatised documentary written and presented by Bill Peach. Edward John Eyre was the first white man to journey across the Nullabour Plain from the east coast to the west coast. He had originally organised and lead an expedition, beginning in Adelaide, that aimed to travel north through Australia’s centre. This attempt was hindered by mirages that prohibited him from finding a break in a series of lakes that would provide access to the north. Defeated by the desert yet determined not to return to Adelaide as a failure, he decided to attempt an east-west crossing that he had previously advised against. Accompanied by his friend John Baxter, his aboriginal guide Wylie, and two indigenous Australians, Eyre veered west. He persevered across the desolate and forbidding landscape, constantly searching for fresh water and shelter from the elements, as he headed for Perth. Unfortunately, Eyre and Wylie were the only two members of the group who eventually reached Perth following a tragic event that claimed the life of Baxter.

results.title: More for less
results.creator_credit: Marty Ostrow, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
A series of case studies which show how fossil fuels can either be used more efficiently or replaced altogether by alternative energy sources. The program stresses, however, that unless the alternatives are shown to be economically advantageous, no matter how environmentally desirable renewable energy sources are, they will not replace fossil fuels in the near future. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Now or never
results.creator_credit: Linda Harrar, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
The concluding episode of this series focuses on individuals and organisations who are fighting for the survival of the planet. It emphasises that whilst international treaties and organisations play a major role, individuals can also make a significant difference. The need for cooperation between all nations, rich and poor, has never been more urgent as “we need to make peace with each other in order to make peace with nature”. Narrated by Karina Kelly. A teacher’s guide accompanies the video.

results.title: The Entertainer
results.creator_credit: Donald Wrye, Beryl Vertue, Marvin Hamlisch, Persky-Bright Productions and Robert Stigwood Organisation
results.brief_description: Coping with constant failures, down and almost out comedian Archie Rice (jack Lemmon) lives with his family and his famous retired father Billy (Ray Bolger). He dreams of the day he will be a star. Cast also includes Sada thompson, Tyne Daly, Michael Cristofer. From the play by John Osborne with music by Marvin Hamlisch.

results.title: It needs political decisions
results.creator_credit: Vivian Ducat, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines the role that governments can play in protecting the environment. In Zimbabwe, President Mugabe talks about the importance of education and of balancing people’s needs against those of the environment. In Thailand, as in Zimbabwe, population growth has been a major problem, and government birth control programs have played an important role in reducing this growth. Popular protest also plays a role in influencing governments, as in Sweden which now has a nuclear ban forced by the people, but care should also be taken that the political decisions made have taken every possible outcome into consideration. Narrated by Karina Kelly. A teacher’s book accompanies the video.

results.title: Race to save the planet
results.creator_credit: Carol Lynn Dornbrand, John Angier, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: A series of programs on the global environmental crisis facing us all. Each program takes an in-depth look at the relationships between human society and the earth’s natural resources, focusing on solutions, constructive ideas and new approaches from all over the world. Each video is accompanied by teacher’s notes.

results.title: Waste not want not
results.creator_credit: Vivian Ducat, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines tales of garbage barges, toxic dumping, overflowing landfills and sewage polluting coastal waters. But it also tells of some imaginative and economically viable ways of not only disposing of waste materials, but also of making use of them for the benefit of the local communities who produce them. Narrated by Karina Kelly.

results.title: Save the Earth, feed the world
results.creator_credit: Andrew Liebman, Edwin Scragg, Jane West, Veronica Young, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines world food production and the challenge of feeding a growing population. The program discusses the environmental damage caused by conventional, intensive farming in both industrial and developing countries and the worldwide movement to replace conventional methods with low-input, sustainable agricultural practices. Narrated by Karina Kelly. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Liebman, Edwin Scragg, Jane West, Veronica Young, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
